column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party; Government of Algeria (2019-)
column17: On 15 March 2020, Algerian police forces dispersed a march in Bouira (Bouira) denouncing police abuses. The protest was organized by activists from Heizar. Three protesters including representatives of the RCD party in the municipality of Bouira were arrested. [size=at least three]

Systematic sexual violence continues to be carried out against Congolese women and girls caught up in mass expulsions from Angola to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a United Nations envoy said on Friday. Community leaders recorded 182 reported rapes in seven villages along the border in January alone, while a UN assessment mission confirmed 1 357 reported rape cases in one village in a six-to-eight-month pe riod last year, said an official. Investigation confirms that violence took place in detention facilitites on both sides of the border.

Mar 23, 2011 (Angola Press Agency/All Africa Global Media via COMTEX) -- The Angolan Armed Forces (FAA) Tuesday in Luanda informed of a clash with a group of the Cabinda Enclave Liberation Front (FLEC), with losses on both sides.The clash occurred on Saturday night in the area of Miconje, northern Cabinda province, the FAA Staff source told Angop.

Angolan border police expelled about 15,000 Congolese in April and May after rounding them up across the north of Angola, according to figures from the aid agency Comitato Internazionale per lo Sviluppo dei Popoli. Since early 2011, the expulsions, frequently accompanied by gang rape and other sexual assaults, have increased steeply.

Angolan border police expelled about 15,000 Congolese in April and May after rounding them up across the north of Angola, according to figures from the aid agency Comitato Internazionale per lo Sviluppo dei Popoli. Since early 2011, the expulsions, frequently accompanied by gang rape and other sexual assaults, have increased steeply.

Angolan border police expelled about 15,000 Congolese in April and May after rounding them up across the north of Angola, according to figures from the aid agency Comitato Internazionale per lo Sviluppo dei Popoli. Since early 2011, the expulsions, frequently accompanied by gang rape and other sexual assaults, have increased steeply.
Angolan police arrested over 20 anti-government protesters on Wednesday (25 May) following a rarely-seen demonstration against the policies of the Dos Santos regime.
300 protesters gathered at Independence Square in Luanda. Police dispersed crowds with batons, teasers and dogs. 16 people arrested, but were released within hours. No mention of serious injuries.
Angolan police held 20 young civil rights activists on Sunday for around three hours for trying to hold a press conference that was interrupted by police.
Angolan police held 20 young civil rights activists on Sunday for around three hours for trying to hold a press conference that was interrupted by police.

About 300 people rallied on September 3rd in Luanda's Independence Plaza, in one of the largest protests yet against President Jose Eduardo dos Santos's 32-year rule. The rally was led by popular rap singers whose rhymes rail against the President. The protesters denounced human rights abuses, shortages of water and electricity, and the poverty that most Angolans endure despite the country's rapid, oil-fueled growth.

Unidentified people killed a youth from Guruvayur in Luanda, the capital city of Angola, on Sunday. The deceased was identified as Ranjith, 35, son of Sambhu Potty of Kallompully Matom at Kottappady, which is located near Guruvayur

A demonstration was held outside the Supreme Court in Luanda to protest the arrest of 21 demonstrators on 3 September 2011. Police used dogs to disperse the crowds and arrested 27 people. No mention of serious injuries.

Angolan police broke up an anti-government demonstration Sunday 10 minutes after about 100 youngsters began a rally in the capital calling for President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos to resign.A substantial police deployment dispersed members of a group calling itself the Young Revolutionaries Movement, sources said.

At least 30 women were kept as prisoners in a dungeon-like structure and gang-raped over several weeks at the Congo and Angola border before being left naked in scrubland. The deportees told the UN that Angolan authorities held them in a dingy building, and added that at least three were killed, including two men and a 27-year-old woman, after being raped repeatedly.
Anti-government protests started in March, growing steadily from small numbers to a crowd of 700 on Saturday, forcing the authorities to beef up security.
Police officers with dogs on Sunday dispersed a spontaneous protest of around 100 young people who had marched to a government building in the capital Luandas southern Viana suburb.

Some 100 Angolans took to the streets Saturday in central Luanda to demand recognition and compensation for a 1977 ruling party purge that killed several thousands in the wake of a failed coup.The march was organized by the May 27 Foundation, which wants the government to launch an inquiry into the events surrounding May 27, 1977, when two senior members of the ruling MPLA led a failed uprising against then-president Agostinho Neto.

column6: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: On 12 February, skirmishes took place in the Munge region, 30 kilometres inland from the town of Bailundo in Huambo Province. Eight people were injured, three of which were police officers.

Anti-government protesters gather to express their discontent of president Jose Eduardo Dos Santos who has led the country since the late seventies. Many of the protesters report an undue heavy handedness by police. At least seven arrested, others beaten.

In December 2011, over 3,000 people took to the streets of Cafunfo to protest against the presence of the private security company Teleservice. The local population blamed the company as the main vehicle for systematic human rights abuses in the region.

Four thousand Angolan war veterans took to the streets of the city of the south-eastern city of Menongue, Kuando-Kubango province, on Saturday, March 31, in protest at delays in the payment of their pensions.

column9: Former UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: 15 armed men in plain clothes and wearing masks on Tuesday night raided a meeting at the home protest organizer and rap musician Casimiro Carbono, causing injuries to three of the ten youths present.

Indian workers continue to be held against their will in the cement factory in which they work after management refused to let them leave after the labor group threaten strike over work conditions. The laborers have been held for several days.
Standoff within a cement factor continues for the final day before Indian nationals are able to return home.

Armed masked men in plainclothes raided at least two gatherings of youth opposition activists and assaulted participants in an apparent intimidation effort. The assailants are believed to be either from the government or hired by them. Exact date(s) unknown.

Angolas government plans to pay overdue subsidies owed to veterans of the long civil war after hundreds of them staged protests in Luanda. ""On June 7 a group of former soldiers headed towards the ministry, demanding their late subsidies,"" the defence ministry said in a statement cited by the Jornal de Angola.
A group of war veterans gathered in Luanda to protest the non-payment of pensions threaten to disrupt upcoming elections if their demands are not met.

Police arrest seven regime protesters and two journalists after they and others clashed with police. The group of 200 had planned to demand the removal of an election candidate of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), saying a criminal conviction disqualified him from running.

column7: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column9: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column17: A protest becomes violent, at least two people were killed and ten injured at an opposition gathering. UNITA has alleged that the unrest occurred when the party refused to allow armed members of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) party to join a meeting in Benguela province. UNITA has since accused the MPLA of intimidating opposition members.

column7: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: An opposition party, UNITA, holds a demonstration against an upcoming election, which they believe to be fixed against them.
War veteran protest an upcoming election believe it to be fixed against their preferred candidate.
A landmine kills four young people aged 13 to 24

15 Angolan oil workers went on strike today aboard the oil vessel FPSO Gimboa, a joint-venture block between Sonangol Pesquisa & Producao and other private countries, to demand better working conditions
Thousands of people marched in a demonstration against violence organized by students
Weapons Seizure: At least 4,439 firearms, including 3,309 AKM type, were collected in Bengo province since the beginning of the disarmament of the civilian population in April 2008.
Last Tuesday, dos Santos led a peaceful demonstration of about 350 former soldiers outside the office of Prime Minister Alberto Vaquina

Angolan police Saturday stopped over 50 protestors gathered in front of the Santa Ana cemetery from demonstrating. The more than 100 police agents were helped by a helicopter, horse-riders and canine and motor-cycle brigades. Angolan police arrested 18 activists staging a rare anti-government rally in the capital Luanda on Saturday, demonstration organizers said.

column6: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: Oil-rich Angolas main opposition party Unita on Tuesday accused civil war foes now in the ruling MPLA of killing one of its activists in an attack in the south of the country. The 42-year-old man and 22 others were building a stage for a party rally in the town Londuimbali south west of the capital Luanda , when he was attacked by armed UNITA supporters. Six others wounded.
A protest by Angolan youths in Luanda - organised against the disappearance of two men over a year ago - was violently dispersed by police forces.

More than 15,000 citizens took to the streets in protest against the wave of brutal murders of female peasants, and the mutilation of their bodies in Cafunfo, Cuango municipality, in Lunda-Norte province. Police and soldiers then conducted door-to-door searches and made arrests.
Defusal: Demining in Okavango-Zambezi Border Zone Runs Smoothly
One person died and three others were injured following a landmine accident

column7: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
column17: Agreement: Signature of an agreement towards military cooperation between Angola, DRC and South Africa
Miner killed by military
Police forces shot a twelve year old child during a sporting match
Protests broke out in response to military shooting of a child. Military dispersed crowd.
Police dispersed youth protest. HRW reported that people were beaten and 22 arrested. No serious injuries reported though.
Police forces beat and detained 3 journalists.
Demonstration against the demolition of mud dwellings in Benguela, Huila and Luanda. Police intervened and held one demonstrator in custody.

column7: MJRA: Movement of the Revolutionary Youth of Angola
column17: Protesters, supported by MJRA, called for an end to President Santos presidency and for the release of two activists in jail.
Students protested for jailed youth activist to be allowed to sit his exams.
Police used tear gas against protesters who gathered against the May killing of activists. 1 person was killed during the protests. Hundreds were arrested.
Police killed two activists Saturday morning, ahead of scheduled protests by UNITA against the May killing of activists.

Protests at funeral of Manuel de Carvalho. Police presence included anti-riot police, mounted police, two water cannons and helicopters. Police threw tear gas to prevent crowd from moving off the planned route. No mention of serious injuries.
Two civilians reported being attacked for being Muslim. Angola reportedly passed a law banning Islam.
MSF stated that about 950 refugee and migrant women from DRC had been raped by Angolan forces between January-November 2013.
Doctors and nurses have engaged in a work stoppage for 48 hours for resolution of a dispute over ""rights and equal wages"", while guaranteeing functioning basic services

column6: ICGLR: International Conference on the Great Lakes Region
column17: Member states of the ICGLR (including DRC, Uganda, Rwanda and Angola) endorsed a general approach for fighting the DRC-based FDLR militia
According to demonstrators, Angolan police beat and detained 20 people protesting against the killing of three activists by security forces
Demobilized soldiers protest to demand payment of pensions.
Youth protesters arrested in Independence Square and beaten with steel cables and truncheons. Protesters were released outside of the city.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) State Security and Intelligence Service
column17: Four protesters demonstrated at Independence Square to demand the resignation of President dos Santos. State Security and Intelligence Service police commanders took two of the protesters to the 1st of May School across the street from Independence Square and beat them with iron bars and sticks.

column7: CICA: Angolan Council of Christian Churches; Women (Angola)
column17: 700 women associated with the Angolan Council of Christian Churches marched in Luanda to mark the start fo 16 days of activism against domestic violence.

column9: Muslim Group (Guinea); Muslim Group (Mali); Muslim Group (Mauritania); Muslim Group (Senegal)
column17: From Dec. 15-25, approximately 3,000 non-Angolan immigrants were violently arrested in Luanda and transported to Trinita detention centre, 30 km from Luanda, where acts of torture also reported. Most of the detained were Muslims from Guinea, Mauritania, Mali and Senegal.
Non-violent activity: The National Demining Institute (INAD) destroyed 871 explosive devices defused from January to March in Okapanda, 14km from Ondjiva in Cunene Province.

column7: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: UNITA members clashed with unidentified group in Cuango Municipality when unidentified group opposed UNITA holding a political rally. UNITAs commune representative was wounded and 9 vehicles damaged.

Religious sect Seventh Day Light of the World attacked police in Sume Mountain, 25 km from Caala, as police attempted to arrest the sects leader Kalupeteka. 9 policemen killed, 13 sect members killed.
1 died, 4 injured in Chitembo, 150km from Cuito, following the explosion of a device.
1 injured when landmine exploded in Ondjivas Caxila III ward.
Protests in Independence Square against arbitrary detention. Police with dogs contained the crowd. One person bitten but no reports of serious injuries. Several arrested, including journalists.
50 protesters demanded the release of arrested activists. Police used batons. Several detained. No reports of serious injuries.
Defusal: 106 unexploded ordance removed from Quessua Hill, Malanje.
100 protesters gather in Luanda to demand the release of 15 activists arrested on June 20. 20 arrested at protests.
18 protested arrested at rally in support of anti-government protesters detained since June.
Defense lawyers protested the mishandling of their clients - 17 youths charged with planning acts of rebellion.
Protests outside courtroom after acquittal of soldier accused of killing an activist in 2013.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) State Security and Intelligence Service
column17: On December 4th, 2015, 18 members of the SIC invaded the house of a civilian (Joao Alfredo Dala) in the neighbourhood Rocha Pinto, in Luanda. They forced the women in the house to get naked, proceeding to harass them, and hit Joao in the face with a gun. Money was stolen and his vehicles as well. After being taken to the police station, he was tortured in several different ways.
Defusal: 239 explosive ordances destroyed in Ombadja.
On January 30th, students protested in Luanda against the elevated increases in costs of university tuition fees. Local police dispersed the crowd without resorting to violence or arrests.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Reports that FLEC killed 30 soldiers this month in two ambushes in Cabinda. First attakck took place on 13 March and resulted in the death of ten soldiers. Military denies ambushes took place.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Reports that FLEC killed 30 soldiers this month in two ambushes in Cabinda. Second attakck took place on 16 March in the town of Buco-Zau and resulted in the death of 20 soldiers. Military denies ambushes took place.
Protests in Luanda after 17 youth activists were sentenced for rebellion.
Police detain and kick several who were protesting the detention and sentencing of 17 activists. One detainee was bleeding and unconscious.
Police shoot at students protesting for extra money for studies. Some students fought back. 3 rioters wounded by gunshot wounds to the legs. 2 police helicopters also intervened.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: The SIC unit burned 2 men to death and executed 2 men publicly

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: The SIC unit executed 3 men at a football field
1 policeman killed, 1 seriously injured by unknown gunmen in Luanda.

column8: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: Three people are killed in a clash between a UNITA delegation and group of youth from Cubal.

column6: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: a delegation of eight UNITA members was attacked while on tour in the town of Capupa in the south of the country by a group of armed men loyal to President Jose Eduardo dos Santos, using batons and machetes. The attackers allgedly carried the flag of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) party. One of the victims died of his injuries.
Vigilante group beat to death an alleged thief.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Fighting between FLEC rebels and the Angolan military occurs in the Belize area from 25 to 28 of July. No casualties mentioned.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Fighting between FLEC rebels and the Angolan military occurs in the Belize area from 25 to 28 of July. No casualties mentioned.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Fighting between FLEC rebels and the Angolan military occurs in the Belize area from 25 to 28 of July. No casualties mentioned.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Fighting between FLEC rebels and the Angolan military occurs in the Belize area from 25 to 28 of July. No casualties mentioned.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: Fighting broke out between the Angolan forces and FLEC. FLEC reported that 11 soldiers were killed near the border with the Republic of Congo.

The military surrounded the area of Zango, outside Luanda. Tractors demolished 300 homes. The military fired shots in the air or at the feet of people who tried to protest. Young people who tried to video the demolitions on their phones were beaten.

column8: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: 6 soldiers were killed when their vehicle was ambushed by FLEC. Two rebels were also killed during these clashes according to a statement released by FLEC.
Over 1000 people who had their homes demolished by the Angolan military protested at the Municipal Administration of Viana.
Civilians had gathered to protest the demolition of homes. The military arrived and fired live ammunition to disperse the crowd. A 14 year old was hit and killed.
3 police officers were killed in clashes with followers from the ""Light of the World Sect""

In response to the death of three policemen in clashes with the ""Light of the World"" sect, the police and military have invaded the village and are attacking followers. 6 people have been reported killed.
Demonstrators calling for the resignation of President dos Santos were attacked by security forces. Many were badly beaten, 8 were dumped on the outskirts of Luanda.
A group of activists protesting human rights violations and abuse of power in Angola were prevented from approaching the site of a planned protest by the Angolan police

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: The SIC unit surrounded and shot the son of a police officer while he was shopping
Employees of Lobito Port are protesting 4 months unpaid wages.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: The SIC unit detained and beat 2 men from Viana, killing one of them

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: The SIC unit shot 6 men

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: A UNITA observer checking the electoral registration process was attacked by a group of 20 MPLA supporters led by a local chief.
Police clashed with protesters demonstrating against the continued demolitions in Zango
Police beat and shot at protesters demonstrating against arrests for land occupations

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: FLEC-FAC claims that they killed 18 FAA operatives. The fatalities were not confirmed by the Angolan Army.

column8: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: Property destruction: The headquarters of UNITA was subject to an arson attack. 2 people have been arrested.
Workers at the Port of Lobito are protesting to demand unpaid wages.
The mother of activist Rosa Kussa Conde was abducted by an unidentified group which demanded that she force her daughter to leave politics.
More than 200 teachers have expressed their anger in the streets and drove to the provincial Education to demand payment of salary arrears. Police swung into action to disperse the protesters.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: FLEC claims that 5 FAA soldiers and 2 FLEC-FAC militants were killed in a confrontation in Micuma. The fatalities were not confirmed by the Angolan Army.
Activists protested against the appointment of Isabel dos Santos as leader of Sonangol. Police attacked the protesters using teargas and dogs. At least one protester wasa critically injured.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: 4 FAA soldiers were killed and many injured when the FAA attacked a FLEC-FAC position. The fatalities were not confirmed by the Angolan Army.
Hundreds of veterans held a protest against the organisers of a veterans organisation who demanded payment for membership.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: An Angolan military patrol ran into FLEC-FAC forces in the village of Mbongozi-Muno, 15km from Buco Zau. FLEC claims that 6 Angolan soldiers were killed and 3 seriously injured in the clash. The fatalities were not confirmed by the Angolan Army.
Students at the Catholic University of Angola demonstrated against the fee increase.
More than 100 workers from the Namibe Provincial Government shipyard protested outside the Provincial court to demand salaries and compensation.

column7: CASA-CE: Broad Convergence for the Salvation of Angola
column17: CASA-CE organised a demonstration in Cacuzo. The police arrested 3 organisers, claiming that CASA-CE did not ask for official permission and that the protesters behaved violently, throwing sticks and stones.

column7: MJSPL: Movement of the People's Protectorate of Lunda Tchokwe
column17: More than 2000 people protested in the streets of Cafunfo, demanding the autonomy of the Tchokwe people.
FNLA members held a demonstration in Malanje on the Day of Martyrs, but the police broke it up, claiming that FNLA had not obtained permission to demonstrate.

Teachers took to the streets to protest evidence of fraud in the hiring process of new teachers. On the same day, veterans from Angola's guerrilla war protested that their pensions have not been paid for 2 months.
Teachers took to the streets to protest evidence of fraud in the hiring process of new teachers. 4 teachers were arrested when the police broke up the protest.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: FLEC-FAC militants claim to have killed 2 FAA soldiers.
On January 24th, policemen killed a civilian.
On January 28, a young man was killed by two unidentified armed men in Viana, Luanda.
Activists advocating that Lunda Sul be made a protectorate protested outside the police station following the release of activists and leaders who had been arrested for planning a demonstration.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: In Bembica Village, near the Lola River, FLEC-FAC forces ambushed a military vehicle, killing 2 soldiers and an officer.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: In Seva Tando-Macuco, FLEC-FAC militants attacked a military patrol. 6 soldiers and 2 FLEC-FAC militants were killed.
Police abducted and tortured Yavo Samuel, who was accused of promoting protests in Cafunfo.

column6: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column8: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: Property destruction: A group of around 40 MPLA elements armed with picks, shovels and machetes stormed and destroyed the UNITA headquarters in Balombo.

column7: MJSPL: Movement of the People's Protectorate of Lunda Tchokwe; Women (Angola)
column17: Following the arrest of 3 activists of the Lunda Tchokwe Protectorate movement, 500 people, mostly women, protested outside the police station until they were released.
Police fired on demonstrators protesting the abduction of Yavo Samuel. 2 people were killed and 8 people were injured.

Demonstrators protested that the Election Commission has been moved to the Ministry of Lands, headed by the Vice-Presidential candidate for the MPLA, Bornito de Sousa. The demonstration was violently suppressed by the police, who set dogs on the protesters and beat them. One of the activists has been abducted.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: FLEC-FAC attacked the Angolan military in the village of Munenga in Cabinda. In retaliation the military arrested many people.

Angolan security forces fought Congolese Kamwina Nsapu militia who had crossed into Lunda Norte border posts from their positions in Congo's Kasai on nine occasions between March-mid-June. In one attack, Kamwina Nsapu militia attacked the Itanda border post, beheading an Angolan border official.

About 200 demonstrators protested under heavy police surveillance in the Angolan capital Luanda against a draft law criminalising all abortions.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: FLEC-FAC claims responsibility for attacks on the FAA in Cabinda in April which killed at least 16 military personnel.

About 50 protesters gathered in Luanda to call for free and fair elections. The police broke up the protest and arrested 7 people.

Angolan security forces fought Congolese Kamwina Nsapu militia who had crossed into Lunda Norte border posts from their positions in Congo's Kasai on nine occasions between March-mid-June. In one attack, Kamwina Nsapu militia attacked the Itanda border post, beheading an Angolan border official.
Police intervened to attempt to prevent a march for accessibility in Luanda. The protesters were prevented from displaying their posters.
Trade union workers held a march for May Day.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: MPLA militants were inspecting voter cards in Bie. Some UNITA supporters refused to show their cards and were beaten and shot at.

column17: FLEC-FAC claims to have taken 4 Angolan police officers hostage on 15 May in an ambush in Buco Zau. The police officers were released on 30 May.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: FLEC-FAC claims that 13 soldiers and 3 FLEC-FAC guerrillas died in attacks on the Angolan military in Cabinda during May.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: MPLA supporters attacked and stoned the Unita cavalcade in Kuito Kuanavale municipality. 2 Unita officials were injured and 3 vehicles were damaged.

Demonstrators gathered to support 7 activists arrested in April. The police dispersed the demonstration. At lease 5 of the demonstrators were arrested and others were beaten. One of the victims suffered serious injuries.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: Non-violent activity: The Angolan police have besieged the Unita officials inside the party headquarters to prevent them from campaigning in Cuando Cubango.

column6: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: MPLA militants ambushed a group of UNITA supporters, who were going to a UNITA meeting in Bocoio. The MPLA militants were armed with sticks and stones, which they used to assault the UNITA supporters. 7 UNITA supporters were injured.

column17: In Saurimo there were clashes during police and protesters demanding independence for the Lunda Protectorate.

column6: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola

People who had been evicted from the Zango settlement blocked the road with burning tires to protest against their treatment by the state. The police arrived and cleared the protesters.
A youth accused of failing to respect a soba and of pulling down an MPLA flag was detained and beaten by the police. He died of his injuries in a cell in Cangola Prison.
An Angolan youth was shot and killed by police officers when he set fire to the MPLA flag in protest the day before national elections.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: A Unita official was abducted by MPLA militants and beaten.
300 people gathered in Namibe to protest the lack of electricity.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: A UNITA delegation was campaigning in Cuima, when they were attacked by MPLA militants, who killed one of the activists.

column9: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola

Staff who had carried out construction work for the military in 2010 protested in Luanda to demand their salaries.

column17: MPLA supporters held a march in Luanda to call for an MPLA victory in the election. MPLA candidate Lourenco joined the march.
