Police officers shot dead a motorcyclist who resisted an attempt to confiscate the motorcycle, sparking a riot from other motorcyclists, who threw stones.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: The police broke up a Lunda Sul UNITA meeting by assaulting officials and firing teargass at them.

column6: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column8: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column17: There were clashes between UNITA and MPLA militants in Bocoio. Residents fled into the woods to escape the violence.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: The son of a UNITA official was shot by police officers in Luanda.

column6: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: 2 UNITA supporters were attacked by MPLA supporters in Monte Belo. The MPLA supporters attempted to throw gasoline and then set the UNITA supporters alight.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: On September 30th, the SIC forces of Angola killed 2 civilians in the street. They were pursuing assailants and two civilians were wrongly caught in the middle. One of them was shot dead in the street, while the other one was shot inside a house.
The National Demining Institute de-mined 400 explosive devices on Friday in the municipality of Dande.
200 workers from Macanagro gather to protest against 5 months of unpaid salaries in Luanda, paralysing activities for an indefinite period of time.

On October 26th, 400 individuals tried to protest on the streets against the slow pace of their reintegration process. They marched through the streets of Luanda till they reached the General Command of the National Police. The police intervened and arrested a few individuals.

column9: CASA-CE: Broad Convergence for the Salvation of Angola
column17: The Angolan Border Police allegedly pursued and beat CASA-CE members who were defending the maintenance of a flag belonging to the organisation. 4 were arrested and 15 are still missing, presumably in the Kingenge woods.

column7: INAD: National Demining Institute; Military Forces of Angola (1975-)
column17: The National Commission on intersectoral demining and humanitarian assistance announced that its project, finished in November 2017 and started on 2016, cleared 143 areas in Cunene of mines.
Civilians of the neighbourhood of Ritondo, in Malange, protested in front of the company for electricity distribution ENA, to protest against the lack of electricity for the previous 2 weeks.
On Tuesday 28th, more than a hundred people started a march in Ndalatando, in the province of Cuanza Norte, in order to protest against violence towards the elderly.

Defusal: the police forces of Angola, in collaboration with INAD, defused a landmine field in Cambandua, after civilians flagged the situation. 8 AKM weapons were found, 11 PKM, a G-3 and thirty two 60mm mortar projectiles. There were also two 81mm projectiles, one 82mm one, two D-30 canon projectives, two spread missiles, 272 ammunitions and 2 other mortars, among other weapons.

Around 20 candidates for teachers protested in front of the Provincial government in Malange on Wednesday 13th. They demanded to know why their files had been returned by the court, which refused around 90 files over bad grades.
The Mines Advisory Group announced on Saturday 16th that it had defused over 476.043 square meters of land in eastern Moxivo province, in Angola, during the last 11 months.

A group of people gathers in Cabinda to protest against violations of human rights, civilian murders, corruption and social degradation. Police arrests 29. Some of the activists who were arrested before managing to start their protest in Cabinda were allegedly tortured.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: A civilian reported torture at the hands of the SIC police. On December 18th, a man was approached by 6/7 SIC agents in a cafe, who arrested him and some other people who were present. They were brought to the 49th police station, known as Esquadra de Nando, where the civilians were tortured in order to confess a crime. Mateus was tortured by the head of the police station until he confessed the crime he was accused of.
A National Police officer was killed on Tuesday 19th December, in Catinton ward Maianga district, in Luanda, by unidentified gunmen who are still on the run.

A group of police members shot against civilians in Cafunfo on December 26th. The event took place when a funeral procession of a young man who has been killed by security forces was taking place. One man was killed during the shooting coming from the police men and two others were injured.

A woman was beaten to death by 2 police members of the Rapid Internvention Unit in Lubango on December 26th. One of the policemen's wallet had disappeared, and the policeman accused the victim of stealing it. The two officers then beat up the victim.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) State Security and Intelligence Service
column17: On January 10th, a dozen armed men decapitated an officer belonging to the information services, carried his head and burned a dozen houses in Kakenge.
On Monday 22nd January, around 20 young people gathered in front of the National Assembly to protest the lack of school rooms in order to study.

Teachers who organised to protest in Benguela, on January 23rd, were dispersed by the local police and threatened with police dogs. The protesters demonstrated against their lack of integration in the education sector in Benguela.

Police intervened in a protest of around 30 students who were demonstrating in Luanda against the so called 'gasosas', fees that are being illegally asked of students to give them have access to education. Students took to the streets on January 26th, but police intervened with dogs and tear gas. One student was injured, though not severely, and 3 were detained over 30 minutes.

column9: MJSPL: Movement of the People's Protectorate of Lunda Tchokwe
column17: On February 24th, police fired live shots at around 4,000 protesters from the Lunda Chokwe protectorate movement who took to the streets in Cafunfu to call for the independence of the Lunda kingdom. 1 killed and 8 injured. Another citizen was allegedly tortured by police. 101 people were detained after the protests in Cafunfo as well as ahead of similar protests planned in Cuango and Capenda-Camulemba.

column9: MJSPL: Movement of the People's Protectorate of Lunda Tchokwe
column17: On February 24th, police activists of the Lunda Chokwe protectorate movement at their homes in Cuango and Capenda-Camulemba ahead of planned protests on that day. 101 people were arrested in total on 24 February in Cuango, Capenda-Camulemba and Cafunfo.
On February 27th, dozens of people protested in Namibe in front of the court against the release of a man who allegedly raped and killed his 14 year old daughter.

Ex members of the Security House of the President of the Angolan Republic marched peacefully on March 5th to demand the indemnities that had been settled for in court, but were prevented from continuing by police.
On March 8, women in Luanda marched in a protest against the violence directed at women in different sectors.
On 17 March, Angolan people took to the street to protest against a bill presented by the president Joao Lourenco himself. This is the first non-repressed protest since the president took office.

Towards the end of the week of March 26th, prisoners at the prison of Luena became rowdy and broke lamps, doors and appliances in protest. Some of the prisoners have been held for longer than their sentences, despite paying their fines and already having received authorisation to be released for parole. They are forced to remain in prison because the local court demands they must pay an indemnity.

On April 4, the public manifestations concerning the National Day of Peace and Reconciliation of Angola turned into a protest against the governance of Norberto Fernandes dos Santos, mainly undertaken by youth. Rioters put up barricades to block the streets and burned tires in protest. The rapid intervention police was forced to intervene.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: On April 4, Criminal Investigation Service policemen (SIC) tortured a man in the province of Uige.

column8: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: On April 4, the Armed Force of Cabinda (FAC) claimred to have killed four soldiers when they attacked the Necuto base in Cabinda.
Strikes: Teachers in Angola start a 2 week national strike over salary increases and working conditions.
On the night of April 11-12, a Guinean civilian was killed in Zona Verde, commune of Viana. Circumstances unclear.

column7: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: On April 14, dozens of people showed up at a protest proposed by UNITA. The protest sought to draw support to the repatriation of capitals while rejected money laundering.
On 26 april, the residents of Agostinho Neto area outside the town of Benguela burnt tires to prevent the demolition of houses by police in the area following a court order.
On April 29, an Angolan police officer killed a young man as he was chasing a foreigner who had escaped from prison in Quimbele.
On April 29, after police killed a civilian, protesters gathered around the municipal police. The police resorted to tear gas to disperse the crowd and injured 2 people.

On May 19, 50 protesters took to the streets in Lubango to demonstrate against the bad governance of Joao Marcelino Tchipingui. The police forces were praised for not stopping or trying to prevent the protest.

column7: INAD: National Demining Institute; Military Forces of Angola (1975-)
column17: Around May 25, the INAD - National Demining Institute - destroyed 14.796 unexploded devices in Icau, Dande.
On March 26, peaceful protesters in Luanda demanding justice for the victims of torture and extrajudicial executions in Angola in 1977 were repelled by police who used dogs.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: On June 1, a SIC policeman pointed his gun at a suspected criminal and shot him in Luanda while he could not get up from the ground. The event happened while the man was taking the 7 police officers to see the pits where he used to dispose of the bodies of the people he killed. According to witnesses, minutes after the first shot, another policeman arrived and shot the man a couple more times. This is another event in the series of killings/assassinations perpetrated by SIC police agents.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: On June 3, MRAn protesters were dispersed by the police while attempting to protest against alleged nepotism and bad governance of the local authorities. The police was accompanied by dogs.
Movement of forces: the Angolan government deployed security forces to the locations of Mbanza Kongo, Soyo, Cuimba and Noqui, between the Angolan province of Zaire and the DRC.

16 June 2018, demonstrators marched in Luanda against the FNLA's violence and the banalisation of criminality in the country under the silence of authorities. The march was organised by the Angolan Observatory for Social Cohesion and Justice, and was later blocked by police.
On July 4, an attack in Viana perpetrated by 30 policemen led to the death of a woman and 3 other people injured.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: On July 6, a UNITA PM was assaulted in his house in Luanda by 5 men wearing the uniform of the criminal investigation service.

On July 10, workers belonging to the Special Brigade for Cleaning the Security House of the Presidency of the Republic were prevented from continuing their protest march in Luanda, during which they demanded their compensation costs to be paid.

column7: ANATA: New Alliance of Taxi Drivers of Angola
column17: On July 14, more than 200 taxi drivers marched in Luanda to protest against the possible (almost certain) increase in fuel prices in the country.
On 16 July, police seized hundreds of motorbikes in Benguela, triggering protests. Police fired teargas, leaving two motorcyclists injured.

On July 21, more than a hundred young people took to the streets of Luanda to claim the 500k jobs promised by Joao Lourenco during the elections. Demonstrations in Malanje and other Angolan cities took place on the same day under the same motto.

On July 21, more than a hundred young people took to the streets of Luanda to claim the 500k jobs promised by Joao Lourenco during the elections. Demonstrations in Malanje and other Angolan cities took place on the same day under the same motto.
On July 25, about 350 workers of the Odilson Santos (SGO) group, a company belonging to the Eduardo dos Santos Foundation (FESA), protested in Luanda against a one-year salary payment delay.

column7: NCMS: Namibe Committee of Syndicated Women; Women (Angola)
column17: On July 28, more than three hundred women marched against sexual harassment in Namibe, under the leadership of the provincial Committee of Syndicated Women.
On August 8, workers at the central Kwanda logistics base in the oil village of Soyo in Zaire province demonstrated against massive lay-offs and low wages.

column9: MIC: Movement for the Independence of Cabinda
column17: Arrests: On August 11, sixteen activists linked to the Movement for the Independence of Cabinda (MIC) (a group of intellectual youth formed end 2017) were detained in Cabinda during a meeting at the residence of MIC President Ngimbi.
On August 15, women demonstrated in Sumbe to raise awareness on gender equality.

column7: CGSILA: General Centre of Independent and Free Unions of Angola
column17: On August 18, some dozen workers from the Angolan National Bridges Company (ENP) marched in Luanda protesting the 57-months salary arrears and called for the intervention of the President of the Republic to address the problem.

On August 30, the representative of the ""Free Hands Association"" in Huambo province accused the national police of several cases of torture in police stations against citizens accused of common crimes. No precise date or location mentioned. The police denied and requested evidence.
Around Sept 2nd (exact date not specified), citizens of Lubango staged a protest against the local government.

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: On Sept 14th, an agent of the Criminal Investigation Service of the province of Cunene, bothered by the noise of a group of minors playing in front of his yard in Ondjiva, voluntarily shot a 12-year-old child, reaching the lower limbs of the girl who received medical care.
On Sept 15th, seven people died after a police charge to evacuate the stadium in Luanda where the football match 1 de Agosto - TP Mazembe had just been played.
On Sept 18th, 500 people (including teachers and students) staged a protest in the city of Namibe demanding Namibe gorvernor's resignation.
On Sept 29th, students from the Clinical Psychology course at the Polytechnic Institute of Malanje and members of civil society held a march to reject suicide and discourage against such practice.

column9: Phende Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Oct 3, a group of locals from the Tchokwe tribe burst into houses of Congolese migrants in Roque neighborhood, Lucapa. Five people were killed with machetes. The migrants are mostly from the Phende tribe.

column8: Phende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On October 4, Congolese migrants mostly from the Phende group armed with machetes and bows and arrows clashed with Chokwe Angolans outside a school in Lucapa in retaliation for a Chokwe attack the previous day. A young girl died. Police fired warning shots to disperse the crowd.
On Oct 4, 80 professors demonstrated in Cabinda in front of the state headquarters to demand an improvement in their situations.

column8: Phende Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Oct 5, suspected fighting between elite police from the Rapid Intervention Police (PIR) and the Chacal (Angola's Israeli-trained special forces branch) and Congolese migrants. At least four injured.

column9: Phende Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On Oct 5, elite police from the Rapid Intervention Police (PIR) and the Chacal (Angola's Israeli-trained special forces branch) were deployed to Lucapa after violence the previous days between locals and Congolese migrants. They killed a man in Kapende and two in Santa Isabel.

On October 5, an Angolan was shot dead by suspected illegal African migrants involved in diamond smuggling in Lunda Norte province.The victim was accused of telling on the smugglers. The attack occurred on the margins of a police operation to arrest and then repatriate thousands of illegal migrants back to their countries.

On Oct 7, a Criminal Investigation Service (SIC) officer shot dead a 24-year-old man who tried to escape arrest in northern Angola's Malanje province. The victim was implicated in various crimes and arrested in the past.
On Oct 8, a fuze mortar detonated when kids were playing with it, leaving one killed and two seriously injured in the Chatala sector, Cela district.

column9: Civilians (Democratic Republic of Congo); Civilians (Lebanon); Civilians (Mali); Civilians (Nigeria)
column17: Over three weeks between 3-21 October, 380,000 illegal migrants mostly from the neighbouring DRC were forcibly repatriated to their countries by the Angolan authorities as part of ""Operation Transparency"". When the operation began, local gangs of Chokwe youth attacked the Congolese migrants in Lucapa, leading to clashes and further violence.
On Oct 18, police forces dispersed a demonstration by ex-workers of the former Special Cleaning Brigade (BEL) in Lunda.

On Nov 17, Angolans from the Revolutionary Movement held a protest near the presidential palace in Luanda to denounce Operation Rescue, carried out by the authorities, as a war against the poor. A number of protesters were reported to have been injured by police forces during the protest.

On Nov 17, Angolan military and police forces responded to a protest in the town of Cafunfo by firing at protesters and beating up a number of them for about 2 hours. 73 were arrested and 4 hospitalised, including one in serious condition.
On November 19, a member of the police forces of Angola sexually abused a 13 year old girl in Luanda.

On November 24, the military forces and the police of Angola forcibly repatriated hundreds of people in Cafunfo, sending around 700 civilians to jail, including locals. Many civilians were assaulted and had personal belongings seized.
On December 3, dozens of ""zungueiras"", women who sell various products on the streets, protested in Luanda against the prohibition to sell their products on the streets.

On December 7, two police officers opened fire and killed a 14 years old girl in Luanda. They were intervening in the activity of local zungueiras, when they opened fire in order to establish order, but one of the shots hit a girl who was passing by the area.

column7: OPEA: Order of Evangelical Pastors of Angola
column17: On December 8, approximately three thousand people led by the Order of the Pastors of Angola took the streets of Luanda to protest for religious freedom.
On December 8, hundreds of people including students, activists and representatives of social movements took the streets of Luanda to protest against unemployment.
On December 8, the police interrupted a protest against unemployment that was about to start in Malanje city. Eight people were taken to the police station.

On December 13, a police officer opened fire and killed a mother and her daughter in Luanda. They were trying to intervene in an argument between a man and the police officer, who had suspected that the man had stolen a gas container.
On December 14, in Luanda, 17 police officers were arrested accused of extortion, missbehaviour and other charges.
On December 15, in Cabinda, a protest for human rights was interrupted by the police, who detained seven activists.
On Dec 23, in Luanda at least 550 people staged a protest against domestic violence against women.
On Dec 24, a fisherman was killed by a policeman in Namibe over unclear reasons.
On Dec 24, eight other ""involuntary"" murders by policemen were reported in the Namibe province.
On Jan 2, a man was abducted and killed by unknown men in Malanje. Reasons unclear.
On Jan 3, Police Forces of Angola have stopped a demonstration performed by the Movement of Angolan Students, protesting against university access fees.

On May 1st, in Luanda, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, the Angolan Trade Union led a march to demand the revision of the new General Labour Law and the end of precariousness. [Size=14.000]
On Jan 7th, in Huambo, Postal Bank customers, mostly motorcycle taxi drivers and small businessmen, demonstrated to demand the restitution of their money. [Size=hundreds]
On January 7th, the chief-inspector of the National Police was killed in his house in Luanda. The killer is unknown.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: On Jan 8th, Military Forces of Angola clashed with Armed Forces of Cabinda (FLEC / FLAC) near Tchiminzi ville in Massabi. 12 people were killed, including 4 civilians.
On Jan 21st, former residents of the Island of Cabo, camped in Viana staged a protest demanding a proper rehousing, as promised by the authorities of the province of Viana.

column9: MIC: Movement for the Independence of Cabinda
column17: On Jan 29th, the Angolan police detained 28 members of the Cabinda Independence Movement (MIC), a few hours before they began a march to mark the anniversary of the Treaty of Simulambuco, which placed that territory under the protectorate of Portugal.
On Feb 16th, in Luanda, doctors protested against the results of the last public tender for the health sector.
On Feb 18th, health workers marched against the entry test system. At least 60 people took part in the protest in Luanda.
On Feb 18th, health workers marched against the entry test system. At least 10 people took part in the protest in Benguela
On Feb 18th, health workers marched against the entry test system. At least 25 people took part in the protest in Huila.

On Feb 19th, in Luanda, former soldiers from various provinces, licensed to join the National Police (PN), demonstrated in Luanda, demanding the reason for the period of five years without a job in the PN and for being unpaid since they were removed from the Angolan Armed Forces (FAA). Tires and sticks were used by rioters. The police intervened to put an end to the demonstration. [size=over 2000]

On Feb 27th, people from Capenda Camulemba, including a number ""sobas"" (traditional leaders), clashed with police and soldiers at the Lulo Diamond Project site over failure to uphold an agreement. One dead and one wounded. The man was killed by a PN agent while dispersing a group of 20 sobas. [size=almost 70]
On March 2nd, in Luanda, hundreds of people marched against domestic violence. [Size=hundreds]
On March 8th, in the municipality of Belas, Angolan women marched demanding an end to violence against women. [Size=300]
On March 12th, in Luanda, residents set tires on the roads to protest the killing of a woman street vendor by a police officer. [Size=unknown]
On March 12th, a woman street vendor was allegedly shot dead by a police officer during ""Operation Rescue"".

On Mar 23th, in Luanda, the Trade Union Force held a peaceful demonstration outside the Hotel Presidente to protest against the dismissal of the first trade union secretary of that hotel unit. [Size=no report]
On April 2nd, police shot dead a man whom they suspected of being involved in an armed robbery that escalatedi into a clash earlier that day in Viana. Populations claim he was innocent.

On April 19th, in Luanda, Angolan activists demonstrated in front of the Parliament demanding to hold the first municipal elections in Angola, scheduled for 2020, simultaneously and in all municipalities. [Size=30]
Around April 20th, over the weekend, a total of 178 citizens were arrested by the Luanda Provincial Command on suspicion of theft and robbery in homes and on public roads.
On April 20th, a 27-year-old citizen was killed by lynching, in Luanda, for shooting and attempting to assault a street vendor. [Mob size=not reported]

On Apr 28th, on the occasion of the World Day of Remembrance for the Victims of Accidents and Occupational Illnesses, in Luanda a march was held to raise awareness on the issue of work accidents and encourage employers to provide adequate working conditions for their employees. [Size=not reported]
On May 18th, an activist and investigator, supported by the work of Police Forces, discovered some mass graves in Calonda area (Lucapa).

On May 22nd, in Vianda, alleged police officers - including two Chief Inspectors of the Migration and Foreign Service (SME) and an agent of the Criminal Investigation Service (SIC) - phyisically assaulted a US citizen, collecting cellphones and attempting a rape.
On May 23rd, workers of the Administration of the Sumbe municipality held a peaceful protest calling for the payment fo their salaries. [Size=120]
On May 25th, young people marched in the streets of Benguela, protesting against the leadership of the provincial governor, Rui Falcao, for alleged ""mismanagement of the province"". [Size=400]
On June 8th, journalists in Luanda marched to protest over violence against children. [Size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column17: Around June 23rd, Criminal Investigation Service (CIS) officers allegedly beat to death a carpenter in Benguela, who was accused of non-compliance with a construction project.

On Jun 27th, in Luanda (municipality of Sambizanga), demonstrators stormed a police station, following the death of a man allegedly killed by police. The man had been arrested several days before on suspicion of drug trafficking. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd, which responded throwing stones. [Size=hundreds]

On Jul 2nd, in Lobito, a protest was held by citizens over the lack of water in the upper part of the city. Seven activists of the Angolan Revolutionary Movement were arrested for allegedly resisting to police officers. [Size=no report]
On Jul 5th, students from the Portuguese School of Luanda held a demonstration in front of the Portuguese embassy to demand greater transparency in the institution's accounts.[Size=50]
On Jul 17th, in Luanda, an 18 year-old was lynched on after killing the woman from whom he had stolen some personal objects. [Size=no report]

On Aug 2nd, former soldiers took part in a violent demonstration in Luanda, claiming entry to the National Police (PN) after having served in the military. Tires and tree trunks were burnt. 11 people were arrested. [Size= no report]

On Aug 13th, protesters gathered in front of the National Assembly in Luanda demanding the holding of municipal elections simultaneously in all municipalities of the country. Police Forces intervened to disperse the crowd. [Size= no report]
On Aug 24th, in Uige citizens and students marched to protest against unemployment. [Size=no report]

On Sept 6th, people in Luanda held a protest demanding the Minister for Youth and Sports, Ana Paula Sacramento Neto and Jofre Euclides dos Santos, director-general of the Angolan Youth Institute (IAJ), to be removed, due to the lack of organisational capacity as the Job Fair recently held. [Size=no report]
On Sept 11th, unknown men attacked a journalist covering a trial session of General Jose Maria, who is on trial for crimes of insubordination and misplacement of military documents.

On Sept 12th, protesters tried to held a peaceful demonstration in Lueana against Governor Goncalves Muandumba. Police intervened before the demonstration started and arrested 23 people. The demonstration had to take place on the same day of President Joao Lourenco's visit in Moxico. [Size= no report]
On Sept 16th, a police officer killed a citizen in Benguela. Circumstances of the killing are not clear yet.
On Sept 21st, people marched in Luanda demanding safer and more inclusive beaches. [Size=no report]
On Sept 29th, a 35-year-old man accused of raping a four-year-old child was lynched by residents of the Green Zone district of Belas district in Luanda.
On Oct 14th 2019, in Alto Catunbela, a 15-year-old died for the explosion of a granade he collected from the ground.
On Oct 15th 2019, in Luanda, a demonstration against unemployment was held. Police beat protesters to disperse the crowd. No fatalities reported. [size=20]
On 16 October 2019, a demonstration against unemployment was held in Luanda (Luanda). Police officers used tear gas and dogs to disperse the crowd. Many people were injured. [size=at least many]

On 18 October 2019, two days after a demonstration against unemployment, the leader of the demonstration disappeared from the Cazenga municipality (Cazenga, Luanda). His wife reported to the police that he had received death threats after the demonstration.
On Oct 22nd 2019, a group of former soldiers held a violent demonstration in the streets of Luanda, demanding to join the national police. [size=no report]

On Oct 26th 2019, students in Luanda held a demonstration against the Government's intention to collect tuition fees for regular higher education starting from 2020. Police intervened firing tear gas to disperse the crowd. [size=200]
On Oct 28th 2019, protests were held in Malanje against the Government's intention to collect tuition fees for regular higher education starting from 2020. [size=hundreds]
On Oct 28th 2019, protests were held in Luanda against the Government's intention to collect tuition fees for regular higher education starting from 2020. [size=hundreds]
On Oct 28th 2019, protests were held in Ndalatando against the Government's intention to collect tuition fees for regular higher education starting from 2020. [size=hundreds]
On Oct 28th 2019, protests were held in Benguela against the Government's intention to collect tuition fees for regular higher education starting from 2020. [size=hundreds]
On Nov 9 2019, residents marched in Ondjiva against domestic violence and child abandonment. [size=no report]
On Nov 19 2019, a Radio Despertar journalist was abducted and tortured by unknown men in Viana. The reasons behind the attack are unknown. No fatalities reported.
On November 27 2019, the Association for the Support of Women Police organized a march in Mbanza Congo (Mbanza Congo, Zaire), to protest against domestic and work violence on women. [size=60]
On November 30 2019, citizens marched in occasion of the World Day of Fight against AIDS in Luanda. [size=no report]

column7: MIC: Movement for the Independence of Cabinda
column17: On December 10 2019, a demonstration was held by the Movement for the Independence of Cabinda, in Cabinda. 15 people were arrested. [size=no report]
On December 11 2019, a journalist was killed by unknown perpetrators in Ondjiva (Cunhama, Cunene). The reasons for the attack are unknown.

column7: UNTA: National Union of Angolan Workers
column17: On December 14 2019, citizens in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) and the UNTA: National Union of Angolan Workers - Trade Union Confederation marched against the cost of living and unemployment. [size=no report]

On December 20 2019, former soldiers of the Angolan Armed Forces held a protest in Huambo (Huambo, Huambo) claiming their place in the ranks of the National Police. Police forces shot at protesters to disperse the crowd. At least three people were injured. No fatalities reported. [size=more than 500]
On December 27 2019, two people were injured in Kilamba Kiaxi (Luanda, Luanda) after mistakenly detonating an explosive device which they had collected as scrap metal. No fatalities reported.

On December 27 2019, pastors and workers of the Universal Church marched in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) protesting against abuses by Brazilian pastors, vasectomy, deviations of tithes and offerings, sale of heritage and other goods. [size=100]

On January 3 2020, workers of the Luanda Cleaning and Sanitation Company (ELISAL) demonstrated in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) damaging company cars and assaulting a driver. Rioters, who demanded better working conditions and the regularization of salary payments, clashed with police. 6 people were arrested. [size=at least 6]

On 5 Jan 2020, in the road between the municipality of Cacolo and the Alto Chicapa commune, five people died and eight were gravely injured after the explosion of a presumed antitank landmine activated by a jeep-like vehicle.

column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: On the week before 7 Jan 2020, in a village in the Ebanga commune, Ganda municipality, Benguela, a member of UNITA (National Union for the Total Independence of Angola) was shot and gravely injured by members of the National Police of Angola. It was reported that the police shot at the citizens. The police declared that the injured tried attacking officers using an arrow.

On January 13 2020, ex-workers of a diamond company gathered in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) to ask for the payment of arrears and the social security cover. Police intervened to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]
Around January 22, students of different universities in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) protested against the increase in tuition fees. [size=no report]

On January 23 2020, police forces halted an attempted protest by people who gathered at the National Assembly in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), to demonstrate in favor of autarchy. Around 10 people (among which journalists and activists) were arrested. [size=at least 10]
On January 28 2020, 24 nurses of the Lubango hospital (Lubango, Huila) held a protest against the violation of their rights by the management of the hospital. [size=24]

On January 29 2020, workers of the Halliburton company gathered in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) to protest against that fact that their wages were not updated at the Central Bank's exchange rate. [size=no report]

On January 30 2020, a motorcycle taxi driver was shot dead in Huambo (Huambo, Huambo) by the police that was trying to disperse a group of citizens accused of riot and physical assault on a suspected motorcycle robber. [size=no report]
Around February 2 2020, a woman allegedly accused of practicing witchcraft was assaulted and killed by four individuals in the Shomokuiyo neighbourhood in Ondjiva (Cunhama, Cunene). [size=four]
On 10 February 2020, more than 90 workers of the Hotel Mombaka, gathered in Benguela (Benguela, Benguela), to demand the payment of the salaries of the last 13 months. [size=more than 90]

On 19 February 2020, a non-authorized protest against the new president of the National Electoral Commission was disrupted by police officers in Luanda. Demonstrators and journalists were hit by officers. 27 people were arrested. [size=at least 27]

column7: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column17: On 22 February 2020, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola organized a march in Luanda, in support of the Party President and Head of State, Lourenco, and against corruption. [size=no report]
On 2 March 2020, students of the Katyavala Bwila University (UKB) in Benguela (Benguela, Benguela) staged a protest demanding more classrooms. [size=no report]

On 9 March 2020, young people held a protest in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), against a supposedly public recruitment at the Military Recruitment Directorate (DRM) that they only became aware of via social media. The police used toxic bombs and fired on the crowd. One man was killed. [size=no report]

As reported on 13 March 2020, residents of Caala (Caala, Huambo) attempted to lynch a couple accused of witchcraft. The couple had dug up the bodies of 10 people, removed their clothes and buried them in their backyard. [size=no report]
On 14 March 2020, dozens of lawyers marched in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) to protest against the state's violations of rights and the prerogative of the exercise of law by magistrates. [size=dozens]

column7: Women (Angola); Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (Angola)
column17: On 14 March 2020, female members of the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God marched against vasectomy in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda). [size=no report]

Between 18 and 20 March 2020, two off-duty police officers wearing uniforms were attacked by security guards from the company K&P, former Project Mineiro Yetwene, in a mining area in Camissombo (Luanda Norte). No fatalities reported.

On 29 March 2020, two soldiers assaulted a street vendor with her baby in Cabinda, under the pretext of compliance with the guidelines under the state of emergency decreed by the Angolan state to contain the coronavirus pandemic.

On 17 April 2020, more than 500 vendors demonstrated against the closure of a local market due to coronavirus restrictions in Caliquembe (Caluquembe, Huila). Rioters, armed with sticks and stones, vandalized several buildings, including the Municipal Administration of Caluquembe and the police and fire department headquarters. The police fired shots to disperse the crowd. [size=more than 500]

Reported on 18 April 2020, vendors held a violent demonstration in Chicomba (Chicomba, Huila) against the closure of a local market as a way to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Rioters vandalized the Municipal Administration building. [size=no report]

column9: BD: Democratic Bloc Party; Albino Group (Angola)
column17: On 29 April 2020, the Provincial Secretary of the Democratic Bloc of Cuanza Sul, was physically and verbally attacked by agents of the national police in Gabela (Amboim, Cuanza Sol). The man was accused of filming, from his balcony, police officers who were preventing people from circulating in the streets. Officers invaded the man's apartment, beat him and insulted him for being an albino. After being forced to enter a patrol car, the man was released when the agents verified that the images did not exist.

On 1 May 2020, more than 100 taxi drivers held a protest in Kuito (Kuito, Bie) against the National Police and the Angolan Armed Forces, for demanding passes for the transport of passengers. Protesters blocked the traffic for an hour. Police forces fired shots in the air to disperse the crowd. [size=more than 100]

On 3 May 2020, a man and a drunk pregnant woman were detained and severely beaten by police officers in Sumbe (Sumbe, Cuanza Sul) for circulating in the streets and allegedly violating coronavirus restrictions. No fatalities reported.
On 6 May 2020, about 200 ex-soldiers, who had been demobilized, demonstrated in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) demanding to be integrated in the National Police. [size=about 200]

On 9 May 2020, 5 police officers beat and arrested a group of citizens consuming alcohol at a canteen, as well as group of nearby youths, in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), during the enforcement of coronavirus measures. The officers opened fire against the group as they tried to run away; a man was shot and killed.

On 9 May 2020, residents stormed and destroyed a police station in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), in response to an attack by police officers on a group of youths for allegedly not respecting coronavirus restrictions. [size=no report]

On 13 May 2020, a teenage boy was shot and killed, and a man was shot and injured as the police opened fire against a group of rioter in Tombas beach square, Benguela (Benguela, Benguela). According to reports, young men working on fishing boats started a clash, the police was called and were received with knifes and wood pieces. Three people were arrested. [size=at least 3]
On 14 May 2020, the explosion of a landmine seriously injured two teenage girls in Ondjiva (Cunhama, Cunene).

On 15 May 2020, a military forces officer shot and injured a teenager in Xa-Muteba (Xa-Muteba, Lunda Norte) for allegedly remonstrating with soldiers during an activity to make citizens aware of the use of facial masks, as a preventive measure for coronavirus.

column9: SINPROF: National Union of Teachers; Teachers (Angola)
column17: On 25 May 2020, three alleged police officers shot dead the General Secretary of the National Union of Angolan Teachers (Simprof) and a man who was with him in the Dangereux district in the municipality of Talatona (Luanda, Luanda).

On 26 May 2020, people who had their motorcycles seized by police between March and April for not having documents or for violating traffic rules, held a demonstration in Benguela (Benguela, Benguela) in front of the Palace of the Provincial Government. 12 people were arrested. [size=at least 12]
Around 27 May 2020 (as reported), a man suspected of having assaulted a motorcyclist was lynched and then charred by residents of Zango (Viana, Luanda). [size=no report]

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column17: Around 2 June 2020 (as reported), clashes were reported between the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda (FLEC) and military forces in the village of Chuvovo in the Massabi area (Cacongo, Cabinda), resulting in the death of about four soldiers of the FAA, two combatants of the FLEC and six civilians.

On 5 June 2020, a teenage boy was killed by police officers in Talatona (Luanda, Luanda) during inspections regarding safety measures during the national coronavirus lockdown. According to witnesses, the officer who shot the boy was drunk.

On 6 June 2020, street vendors rioted against police officers who were trying to disperse traders from an irregular market in the Campo da Aviacao neighbourhood in Caluquembe (Caluquembe, Huila). During the riot, a female street vendor was fatally shot. [size=no report]

On 9 June 2020, several employees and patients of the Multiperfil Clinic in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), demonstrated in the main park of the hospital unit, demanding the results of their coronavirus tests and the lifting of the sanitary corden installed since 30 May 2020 because of three positive cases of coronavirus recorded in the clinic. [size=several]

On 11 June 2020, taxi drivers held a demonstration against the unilateral decision of the city administration to define new routes and stops for vehicles used for taxi services. Demonstrators blocked traffic on a stretch of the EN-100 between Cimangola and the municipality of Cacuaco (Cacuaco, Luanda). [size=no report]

On 16 June 2020, a man died after he was intercepted by the police and ordered to perform somersaults with a gun pointed towards him in Palanca neighborhood, Luanda (Luanda, Luanda). The order was given because he was not wearing mask under the coronavirus health measures. The man had heart problems and hypertension.

On 18 June 2020, dozens of motor taxi drivers demonstrated in Namibe (Namibe, Namibe) against what they claim to be police harassment during the enforcement of laws to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Protesters reported that police officers had been pursuing them even after the loosening of the emergency phase restrictions. [size=dozens]
On 24 June 2020, three civilians were killed by military forces at Macama-Nzila village in the Cabinda area (Cabinda, Cabinda) during coronavirus-related policing.

column9: UCI: Union of Cabindeses for Independence; Prisoners (Angola)
column17: On 28 June 2020, the UCI president and vice-president were reportedly tortured by police officers in Cabinda (Cabinda, Cabinda) after going to the station to report a kidnapping attempt by an unidentified group. Both men and the director of the president's office were arrested, accused of rebellion, outrage to the State and criminal association.

On 3 July 2020, two street vendors were beaten by nine inspectors of the Municipal Administration of Lubango (Lubango, Huila) for selling fruits in the proximity of an established company. One of the woman was severely injured and was in coma after being treated at the hospital. One of the inspectors was arrested the following day.

On 3 July 2020, a teenage boy was shot, beaten and killed by police in Cazenga (Cazenga, Luanda) during national coronavirus lockdown enforcement. The victim was playing football with friends when the officers arrived in a car and opened fire against the group; the boy fell, and 3 officers stepped out of the car and kicked him, leaving after.

On 4 July 2020, a teenage boy was shot and killed by 3 police officers and 2 members of the armed forces in Cacuaco (Cacuaco, Luanda) during the national coronavirus lockdown inspections. According to witnesses, the victim was chased and shot; the officers poured water in this face as he was down and then shot him in the face.

On 4 July 2020, dozens of people took to the streets of Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) in a demonstration against the MPLA, government measures to deal with the coronavirus, and corruption, among other things. [size=dozens]

column6: FLEC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
column17: On 7 July 2020, a clash between FLEC and armed forces was registered in the villages of Pangamongo and Sangamongo near Buco Zau (Buco Zau, Cabinda). During the shoot-out, three soldiers and two civilians were shot and killed; three other soldiers were injured. A FLEC announcement stated that at least 22 members of the armed forces died.

column16: 24 Horas; O Pais; Correio da Kianda; Club K; Ango Noticias; Angola Press Agency; Jornal de Angola
column17: Around 12 July 2020 (as reported), a group set tires on fire and barricaded the main street of Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) after a man was shot and killed, and another injured by the National Police in Prenda neighborhood. The Police was called to disperse the group. [size=no report]

Around 12 July 2020 (as reported), 10 houses were burnt after unidentified individuals set vegetation on fire in Mungo (Mungo, Huambo). According to information, the owners were suspects of witchcraft and the crime took place after a resident died, allegedly by a witch. No reports on injuries and/or fatalities. [size=no report]

column16: Jornal de Angola; O Pais; Ango Noticias; Amnesty International; Angola Press Agency; Club K; Correio da Kianda
column17: On 13 July 2020, the National Police shot and killed a man, and shot and injured another in Prenda neighborhood, Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), during the national coronavirus lockdown inspections. A police officer was arrested.

On 15 July 2020, more than 50 people demanded Justice during the funeral procession of a man killed by the police on 12 July 2020 for not wearing a mask in Luanda (Luanda). The group demanded the perpetrator to be held responsible. Police intervened. [size=more than 50]

column7: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (Angola)
column16: 24 Horas; Correio da Kianda; Angola Press Agency; Club K; Jornal de Angola
column17: Around 21 July 2020 (as reported), 40 armed individuals attacked national members of the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (IURD). According to a published note by the Angolese IURD, the group was hired by a Brazilian bishop of the church and is part of a campaign against Angolese bishops and pastors. Injuries and/or fatalities were not reported.

column7: PRA-JA: Angolan Renaissance Party - Together for Angola Serving Angola
column17: On 22 July 2020, supporters of Albel Chivukuvuku were stopped and beaten by the police in Luanda (Maianga, Luanda) during a demonstration against the govenrnment's refusal to recognise the PRA-JA as a political party. It was not reported whether people were injured. [size=no report]

Around 25 July 2020 (weekend of), a man was beaten by a police officer in Quipungo (Quipungo, Huila) for allegedly having violated sanitary measures related to the coronavirus lockdown. The officer shot at the man, but he was not injured.

On 25 July 2020, a man was killed by police officers and private security officers in the Mbuli forest, Binga village, Buco Zau (Buco Zau, Cabinda) while mining gold with another person. The private security officers were hired by a mining company.

Around 26 July 2020 (as reported), a man was shot and killed by a private security guard in Uige (Uige) after the victim tried to enter a building without wearing a mask during the national coronavirus lockdown. The security guard was arrested; his gun seized.

column6: FLEC-FAC: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda-Armed Forces of Cabinda
column16: Correio da Kianda; VOA; 24 Horas; DW
column17: Around 28 July 2020 (as reported), an armed clash between the FLEC/FAC and the Military Forces was registered in the village of Chissanga, region of Massabi (Cabinda, Cacongo). During the shoot-out, 8 armed forces soldiers and 2 members of the Cabinda Liberation Front were killed. The independency group also seized heavy armaments from the State forces.

column7: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (Angola); Protestant Christian Group (Angola)
column16: Correio da Kianda; Jornal de Angola
column17: On 2 August 2020, more than 100 members of the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God supporting the church's Brazilian leadership demonstrated in front of the Maculusso Cathedral in Luanda (Lunda) against the reforms demanded by the Angolese wing of the church and to prevent an Angolese bishop to take control of the Cathedral. [size=more than 100]

Four people were arrested and stated that the police tried to run over demonstrators. [size=dozens]
On 4 August 2020, armed forces and the police killed three individuals for suspected links to the FLEC-FAC during a patrol in the village of Binga-Grande, Buco Zau (Buco Zau, Cabinda).

column16: Correio da Kianda; Policia Nacional de Angola
column17: On 5 August 2020, dozens of people staged a demonstration in Caxito (Dande, Bengo) in support of employees who had not received their wages and against the lack of water supply in the region. Police used tear gas and live fire to disperse the demonstrators for not obeying protest and coronavirus-related rules. Police also ran over the coordinator, arresting him and other 3 people. [size=dozens]

column16: Correio da Kianda; Jornal de Angola
column17: On 9 August 2020, the police clashed with a group keeping a man hostage after he tried to burn his wife in Ucua (Dande, Bengo). Upon rescuing the man, the group threw stones and used other objects against the officers, also destroying the police and firefighters station. The officers retaliated using fire guns; 4 civilians and 2 police officers were injured. 6 people were arrested. [size=at least 6]

On 15 August 2020, an activist was beaten and arrested by the police for not wearing a mask during coronavirus-related policing in Lobito (Lobito, Bengela). According to reports, he was attacked for being one of the organizers of a demonstration scheduled for September, and not for not wearing a mask.

column16: Correio da Kianda; Jornal de Angola
column17: On 20 August 2020, around 300 former military forces members took to the streets in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) to demand the payment of reposition wages, halted due to the coronavirus pandemic and to demand their integration in the police. The police disperse the group and arrested at least 29 individuals. [size=around 300]

column7: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (Angola); Protestant Christian Group (Angola)
column9: Universal Church of the Kingdom of God (Angola); Protestant Christian Group (Angola)
column17: On 21 August 2020, a member of the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God was injured after members of the Angolese wing and Brazilian wing clashed in front of a temple in Comercial neighborhood, Lubango (Lubango, Huila). A group against the church reform was demonstrating against changes when they started the attack. The police was called to disperse the groups. [size=no report]

column16: 24 Horas; Amnesty International; VOA; Correio da Kianda
column17: On 22 August 2020, a man was shot and killed by police in the Distrito Urbano do Zango 3, Viana (Luanda, Luanda), for allegedly not wearing a mask despite coronavirus health measures. An officer was arrested.

Around 27 August 2020 (between 27 and 28 August), a man was killed by a mob and his body found burnt in Muxima-Moxi neighborhood, Zango (Viana, Luanda), after he, and other 2 people robbed a woman. The other 2 evaded the mob. [size=no report]

Around 28 August 2020 (as reported), 3 individuals were killed and burnt by a mob in Boa Esperanca neighborhood, Zango (Viana, Luanda). The 3 were allegedly part of a group that was bothering residents. [size=no report]

On 28 August 2020, a political activist was shot 7 times and injured by police officers on the road between Uige and Negage (Uige, Uige). The victim was transporting individuals when the police ordered him to stop and opened fire. According to the activist, his death was ordered by the province's governor and police commander as he was organizing a demonstration.

column7: MPLA: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
column9: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
column17: Around 1 September 2020 (as reported), members of the UNITA were attacked with stones, machetes and knifes by MPLA members in Vacaria neighborhood, Cubal (Cubal, Benguela). The group were in the neighborhood to raise an UNITA flag; 5 people were injured and the flag was destroyed. [size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of Angola (1975-) Criminal Investigations Service
column16: 24 Horas; Correio da Kianda; Novo Journal
column17: On 2 September 2020, a SIC chief was assaulted, beaten, and physically forced to leave a governmental building by around 30 municipal inspectors in Zango 3, Viana (Viana, Luanda). The inspectors accused him of illegally possessing of land; the chief was present in the building to respond to a call concerning the land, which is legally his. 6 inspectors were arrested. [size=around 30]

On 4 September 2020, former teachers of the Methodist University of Angola gathered in front of the institution and the Central Methodist Church's main residence in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) for a vigil and demonstration regarding the non-payment of the compensation they are entitled. [size=no report]

column16: 24 Horas; Jornal de Angola; Novo Journal; Correio da Kianda; Lusa
column17: On 10 September 2020, a group tried to invade a police station in Cazenga (Cazenga, Luanda) after a robbery suspect was arrested and residents of the Ossos neighborhood were unhappy with they way he was being treated. An officer shot in the air to disperse the group, hitting and killing a pregnant teenager. Rioters then set the station on fire. The officer was arrested. [size=no report]

On 12 September 2020, around 300 doctors, and hundreds of students, politicians, health workers, and members of the civil society took to the streets in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda), in a demonstration against police violence. [size=hundreds]

column16: Jornal de Angola; Angola Press Agency
column17: On 13 September 2020, 46,800 explosive devices were destroyed in Ondjiva (Cuanhama, Cunene). The devices were gathered during 2 months of operations in the villages of Namacunde, Cuanhama, Cuvelai and Ombadja.

On 14 September 2020, street traders threw objects at 5 police officers in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) as the officers tried to enforce the ban on street sales on unauthorized days (as part of coronavirus-related measures). A police officer was injured. [size=no report]

column16: DW; VOA; Angola Press Agency; Jornal de Angola
column17: On 17 September 2020, 10 demonstrators were beaten and arrested by the police in Calandula (Calandula, Malanje) as the group were preparing to demonstrate against the living conditions in the province and to demand the exoneration of the local administrator. The group was released on 24 September 2020. [size=at least 10]

On 19 September 2020, 15 demonstrators were beaten and arrested by the police in Malanje (Malanje, Malanje) as the group was preparing a vigil against the police intervention in another demonstration on 17 September (coded separately). One demonstrator was injured and taken to the hospital. [size=at least 15]

column16: Jornal de Angola; Angola Press Agency; O Pais
column17: Around 23 September 2020 (week of), a man was buried alive in the Vavayela village, near Huambo (Huambo, Huambo) accused of stealing onions in a field. The 5 perpetrators were arrested. [size=5]

On 24 September 2020, 60 miners, who previously worked for mining projects of the Luachimo Mining Society, gathered in front of a diamond company in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) to demand the compliance of agreement regarding the halt of activities in 2008. [size=60]
On 26 September 2020, 200 people took to the streets in Luanda (Lunda, Luanda) in a demonstration to demand justice in what they say is a 200 million dollar scam from a real state company. [size=200]

column7: Labour Group (Angola); MEA: Movement of Angolan Students; Street Traders (Angola); Students (Angola)
column17: On 26 September 2020, during a demonstration against unemployment, a group of 200 demonstrators threw objects at members of the Ministry of Interior in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda). column16: Angola Press Agency; Jornal de Angola; O Pais
column17: On 27 September 2020, 2 individuals were beaten to death by a group in Vila da Graca neighborhood, Huambo (Huambo, Huambo), accused of cattle theft. [size=no report]

On 29 September 2020, about 200 employees of a bank gathered in front of the institution in the Marginal de Luanda, Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) in a demonstration against the group's lay-off. According to the group, the lay-off was not in accordance to the Labor Law. [size=about 200]

On 3 October 2020, around 100 people took to the streets in Lunda (Luanda, Luanda), to demand the resignation of the President's cabinet director for allegedly being favored by the state in contracts worth millions. The group also demonstrated against the lack of a social communications office for the country. The riot police oversaw the demonstration. [size=around 100]

On 12 October 2020, displaced residents of the Salinas neighborhood were injured by the police canines during a demonstration in Benguela (Benguela, Benguela) against the sale of the plots of which they were ordered to leave. The police also used tear gas and arrested 14 people, including a journalist who was filming the demonstration. [size=no report]

Around 14 October 2020 (as reported), a farmer was tortured and injured by a group in a village near Bocoio (Bocoio, Benguela). The group ordered the man to leave the village because his father was accused of criminal actions; the victim asked the Justice to consider the event as ethnic violence. [size=no report]
On 16 October 2020, displaced residents of the Salinas neighborhood took to the streets in Benguela (Benguela, Benguela) in a demonstration against their eviction from the area. [size=no report]

column16: 24 Horas; O Pais; VOA; Ango Noticias; Angola Press Agency; Jornal de Angola; Novo Journal; Lusa
column17: On 20 October 2020, Sequele residents set objects on fire, set up barricades and attacked members of the municipal administration in the outskirts of Cacuaco (Cacuaco, Luanda) as a group of officials went to the region after the government announced the demolition of irregular houses. The National Police was called to control the situation. During the event, a man was shot and killed by an unidentified individual (allegedly a police officer). At least 3 other people were injured. Around 50 were arrested. [size=no report]

column7: UNITA: National Union for the Total Independence of Angola; Labour Group (Angola)
column16: Angola Press Agency; Lusa; VOA; 24 Horas; Correio da Kianda; Novo Journal
column17: On 24 October 2020, around 2,500 demonstrators took to the streets in Luanda (Luanda, Luanda) against the high cost of living in the city and unemployment. A group set objects and a police unit on fire and stoned police cars, who responded with tear gas. Dozens of officers from the Rapid Intervention Unit with canine and cavalry brigades were at the demonstration. Between 40 to 50 people were arrested. The demonstration was supported by UNITA; one of its deputies were injured and arrested. [size=around 2,500]

Police in Botswana fired tear gas on rioting students angry over a teachers strike. Teachers union secretary Justin Hunyepa says the students rioted in Molepolole, some 30 miles (50 kilometers) outside Gaborone, on Friday. He says 95 per cent of teachers are on strike nationwide

Botswanas striking government employees caused public disorder in the African countries second city Francistown on Tuesday as thousands of strikers barricaded roads with burning tires. According to local radio GABZ, the striking workers in the city took to the streets, barricading roads, burning tires and even throwing stones at passing cars. The police had to use tear gas to disperse the rioters, some workers have been arrested by the police.
Violent protests by Botswanas public service workers, who are embroiled in a wage dispute with President Ian Khamas government.
After a football game, minor riots erupted at the stadium. A football assaulted a journalist for taking his photo.
On 13 March 2014, a man was arrested for trading in elephant tusks. He accused police of torturing him during his arrest in Maun.

Kalahari Bushmen protested at an election rally for President Ian Khama over their right to hunt on traditional lands. Khama has been criticized for attempts to force the Bushmen out of the reserve while allowing fracking exploration and a diamond mine on the land.
YWCA silent protest march to end gender-based violence.

Rioters gathered at the Oodi sub-land board to submit applications for residential land plots. They spent the night in the queue and brought down the main gate of the offices and broke windows during the night.
Protesters gathered at different land boards in Kgatleng District to submit applications for residential land plots.

Property destruction: Botswana Defence Forces raided and burned four temporary fishing camps villages in Linyanti, where BDF claimed Namibian fishermen were conducting illegal fishing. Several arrested.
Botswana police detain and beat Zimbabwean immigrants with canes, causing severe injuries.
Churches in Kumakwane staged a march against gender based violence.
Rioters threw stones, burned tyres, and destroyed a shopping centre in protest of four men being on trial for allegedly murdering a woman. Police arrested 5.

Students at Gabarone Technical College and Francistown College of Technical Education rioted on Feb 22 over non-payment of allowances and issues of accreditation - erected barricades, pulled students from class.

Students at Gabarone Technical College and Francistown College of Technical Education rioted on Feb 22 over non-payment of allowances and issues of accreditation - erected barricades, pulled students from class.
A group of women staged a sit-in protest at the SADC headquarters in Gaborone in Botswana.

Unemployed youth peacefully picketed the Botswana Parliament. Armed police demanded that the youth disperse and then began to arrest and beat them. A journalist was arrested for refusing to delete footage of the police violence. No injuries reported.
On 4 February, religious followers, together with the police, mobilised the public in a march against murder in Kgatleng.

On 6 March, student riots took place at the Botho University main campus in Gaborone. The student's riots at Botho follows last month's protests over book allowances and accreditation of courses offered by the institution.
On 4 April, residents of Tlokweng protested an illegal water siphoning connection attached to the Notwane river system by Iranian born real estate magnate.
On 24 May, a young man from Mandunyane village suspected to be a robber and rapist was beaten by mob. He survived.

column7: BOFEPUSU: Botswana Federation of Public Parastatal and Private Sector Union
column17: On 28 March, Botswana Federation of Public Parastatal and Private Sector Unions (BOFEPUSU) held a demonstration against corruption in Gaborone

On 28 May, a group of unemployed teacher graduates that marched to the Ministry of Basic Education in Gaborone to hand over a petition has given Minister Bagalatia Arone 20 days to have responded to their demands.

On 18 June 2018, a group of 12 refugees from Namibia demonstrated in front of SADC headquarters in Gaborone, demanding their grievances be addressed over a decision to repatriate the refugees to Namibia next month. The demonstrators are demanding the Namibian government to unban the United Democratic Party (UDP), which carried out deadly secessionist attacks. [size=12]

On 19 June 2018, a group of 12 refugees from Namibia demonstrated for the second day, in front of SADC headquarters in Gaborone, demanding their grievances be addressed over a decision to repatriate the refugees to Namibia next month. The demonstrators are demanding the Namibian government to unban the United Democratic Party (UDP), which carried out deadly secessionist attacks. [size=12]
On 9 October, Mokolodi residents barricaded the road leading to the quarry in protest against the pollution and dust caused by construction tipper trucks that pass through the residential area.

End September/early October, a man was killed by an angry mob that attacked him near Sedumedi JSS after being found with electric cables inside his bag, which they alleged he had stolen from inside people's houses
On 3 October, a peaceful demonstrations by students took place at the University of Botswana in Gaborone.
On 9 October, Mokolodi residents barricaded the road leading to the quarry in protest against the pollution and dust caused by construction tipper trucks that pass through the residential area.
On 21 November (exact date unknown) , disgruntled employees of United Refineries Botswana stormed owning MP's constituency office demanding payment.
06 February. Students from the University of Botswana protested at the university over the delayed welfare allowance payments.
On or around 26 April 2019, residents from Jackalas No1 village marched to hand over a petition to the member of parliament due to a persistent water crisis in the area. [size=no report]

On 18 June 2019, five University of Botswana students were arrested for blocking the entrance of the Department of Tertiary Education Financing, to demand that their allowances be paid. [size=at least 5]
On 19 June 2019, students marched to the Department of Tertiary Education Funding Office in Gaborone to demand that their allowances be paid. [size=no report]

17 July. Residents from Selebi Phikwe held a peaceful demonstration to put pressure on the District Commissioner to deal with the earth tremors in the town that is being caused by underground shifts at the now closed BCL mine. [size=no report].

On 20 July 2019, mine workers along with the BMWU demonstrated at the Gaborone International Convention Centre during the 50th anniversary of Debswana mining company. The demonstrators were demanding a bonus increase. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2019, students from the University of Botswana, Gaborone, staged four days of demonstrations at the university over the late payment of allowances and the shortage in accommodation. [size=no report]

On 13 August 2019, students from the University of Botswana, Gaborone, staged four days of demonstrations at the university over the late payment of allowances and the shortage in accommodation. [size=no report]

On 14 August 2019, students from the University of Botswana, Gaborone, staged four days of demonstrations at the university over the late payment of allowances and the shortage in accommodation. [size=no report]

15 August (on or around). Students from the University of Botswana, Gaborone, have been demonstrating at the university for four days over the late payment of allowances and the shortage in accommodation. [size=no report].

19 August. Demonstrations have been reported the Gaborone University College of Law and Professional Studies (GUC). The demonstration is over a lack of lecturers, delayed allowance payments and overcrowding. [size=no report].

Around 15 December 2019 (month of), a young man was beaten and left with scars after a mob attacked him in Mogoditshane (Kweneng South, Kweneng). He was allegedly targeted for having links to a youth with a criminal history in the village. [size=no report]
On 5 January 2020, a mob beat to death a young man after he was allegedly caught stealing at Mogoditshane's Senthumole ward in Mogoitshane (Kweneng South, Kweneng). [size=no report]
On 5 January 2020, a mob killed a man suspected of stealing a vehicle in Senthumule ward in Mogoditshane. [size=no report].

On 13 January 2020, a mob attacked a man and a village chief who they accused of murdering another man in the community. The incident came after the body of a man was found who were missing since December in Paje village. Four people were injured by the village chief and 39 arrested. [size=at least 43]
On or around 26 January 2020, a Zimbabwean national was fatally assaulted in Gaborone by community members who accused him of pickpocketing. [size=no report]

On 9 May 2020, around 30 local residents staged a demonstration outside the home of the councillor in Boswelakoko/Saint Paul ward near Molepolole (Kweneng) to demand food relief hampers during the coronavirus lockdown. [size=around 30]

On 27 June 2020, 4 safari guides were beaten by 4 anti-poaching soldiers and 2 wildlife officers in the Okavango Delta's NG32 area (North-West). The victims were suspects in using a vehicle with mismatching registration number plates and were accused of poaching.

On 25 July 2020, a man was shot by a rubber bullet and seriously injured by police officers in Gaborone (Gaborone, South-East) after the group was approached for not obeying coronavirus-related rules.

On 8 September 2020, students from the Moshupa secondary school attacked teachers and damaged property, including cars, in Mosopa (Ngwaketsi, Southern). The motivation for the violence was unknown. No reports on injuries. [size=no report]

On 28 September 2020, Botswana International University of Science and Technology students were injured as riot police fired teargas canisters inside their rooms in Palapye (Palapye, Central). The students had announced a strike against the BIUST varsity's management. 6 students were injured.

Around 5 October 2020 (as reported), a group of 40 female lawyers danced in front of the High Court in Gaborone (Gaborone, South-East) to raise awareness against gender-based violence, and to raise funds for the cause. [size=40]
A grenade exploded in Burundis capital Bujumbura as revelers were ushering in the new year, killing three people and wounding three others, the army spokesman told AFP on Saturday.

On 7 January 2011, in a separate incident three children, aged three to 11, and a domestic worker were found burned to death after an unidentified armed group threw a hand grenade in an attack on their home in a southern district of the capital Bujumbura. The attack in the Kanyosha district , where much fighting goes on between FNL supporters and main party, targeted the home of a salesman and led to the explosion of a motorbike which was inside the house, witnesses said.

Gunmen attacked a police post in Burundis Bujumbura Rural Province, local media reported on Tuesday. The attackers launched the raid on Monday night on Muyira in the hilly Kanyosha Community, 12 km southeast of the capital Bujumbura. No casualties have been reported.
Two people were killed and another one injured in a grenade explosion that targeted a house where the three victims were sleeping early Wednesday morning at Kinama slum, in Bujumbura

Gunmen attacked a police post in the town of Gihanga in the province of Bubanza, some 15 km west of the Burundian capital Bujumbura, the Burundian police spokesman told Xinhua on Friday. Witnesses said those gunmen burned the local office of the ruling Counsel National pour la Defense de la Democratie-Forces de Defense de la Democratie (CNDD-FDD) at Gihanga before fleeing
Two killed by unidentified men in Mutakura, in Cibitoke urban commune.
Hundreds of Burundians living with HIV/AIDS recently staged a demonstration in the capital, Bujumbura, to protest against a lack of treatment.

column9: ADC: Democratic Alliance for Change Supporters
column17: In Burundi, three people were killed on the outskirts of the capital, Bujumbura on Thursday [14 April] night. The victims included two opposition supporters. Burundian authorities say the attacks were carried out by armed bandits, but local residents say the three people were killed in executions carried out by secret service agents.

column6: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column17: At least six people died on the outskirts of the Burundian capital at the weekend in reprisal killings between the ruling party and the former rebel National Liberation Forces (FNL), officials said Monday. Of the six, four were killed because they belonged to the ruling party and the remaining two because they belonged to the FNL, local people and officials said.
About 100 journalists marched here Tuesday to press for the release of a jailed colleague, the decriminalization of press offences and to mark World Press Freedom Day.
Gunmen shot dead five people in attacks in Burundi, police said yesterday, the latest in a series of murders that are raising fears of a new rebellion.

column9: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column17: Attackers killed four people and wounded five as they watched television at the home of a ruling party member, witnesses and a local official said on Sunday.

column7: FRONABU-Tabara: Front for National Revolution in Burundi (Tabara Faction)
column17: The authorities in Burundi have arrested five suspects following attacks on two police checkpoints near the capital, Bujumbura, on 4 July 2011, with the attackers reportedly claiming political motives. Agence France-Presse (AFP) also cites the police as referring to the leaflets, which reportedly stated, ""We are not armed bandits, but FRONABU-Tabara (Burundi National Front) fighters, and we have political demands.""

At least nine people have been killed in western Burundi in the latest battles between the country's security forces and unidentified gunmen on 19 and 20 July. The most recent incident occurred when the gunmen ambushed a taxi in the north-west Cibitoke province, leading to the death of two soldiers, a police officer and six ""gangsters"", according to Agence France-Presse (AFP).

Three people were killed in the south of Burundi after a clash between police and gunmen in the latest in a series of violent incidents that have increased fears of a new insurgency in the central African nation. two armed men and a police officer were killed in a clash on Tuesday in Kizuka village in the southern district of Rumonge, Gerard Ndikumana, a district official, said on Wednesday.
Three gunmen were killed in the Burundian capital Bujumbura on Sunday (7 August) in a shootout with police, who seized guns, hand grenades and ammunition following the clashes.

Gunmen killed one soldier and seriously wounded five people in western Burundi, the latest attack in a spate of violent incidents that have raised fears of a new insurgency. In Wednesdays incident, armed men in the western district of Gihanga ambushed and killed a soldier and wounded five people, including two nuns and a priest, an official said. - Reuters

Gunmen killed one soldier and seriously wounded five people in western Burundi, the latest attack in a spate of violent incidents that have raised fears of a new insurgency. In Wednesdays incident, armed men in the western district of Gihanga ambushed and killed a soldier and wounded five people, including two nuns and a priest, an official said. - Reuters

Police killed two gunmen in Burundis capital after a heavy exchange of fire, police said on Tuesday, the latest in a series of incidents that have raised fears of a new rebellion in the coffee producing nation.
Five members of a former Burundian rebel group were forced to seek refuge in a human rights commission because security forces are allegedly trying to kill them, the men said Friday.

Two people were killed and three others injured on Sunday, as police officers clashed with students at the Mutunga university campus in Burundi during a search operation, reliable sources have told APA.

Burundi police killed four gunmen after a heavy exchange of fire, a police officer said on Monday, the latest in a series of violent incidents that raise concerns about a new insurgency in the coffee-producing nation.The clash took place late on Sunday in the western province of Cibitoke

Dozens of armed men opened fire on a restaurant outside Bujumbura, killing four people, witnesses and a local official said on May 29th. Local administration official Abdul Bampoye blamed the attack on 'armed bandits' but witnesses said the attackers were part of a new rebel movement.

column8: CNDD-FDD: National Council for the Defence of Democracy-Forces for the Defence of Democracy
column17: Two ruling party militants were killed by armed men on the night of May 30th in Bujumbura Rural province, one of the worst-affected areas.

Gunmen stormed a bar in Gatumba area, some 13 km west of the capital Bujumbura and close to the border with the Democratic Republic of Congo, killing at least 36 people. Witnesses said the gunmen, some disguised as policemen, burst into the bar late on September 18th, forced its patrons to the ground and raked the interior with bullets
Security forces shoot and kill 18 armed rebels. Many of the others fled across the border into Tanzania.
Police forces quickly arrest two individuals in connection with an attack on a mission.
Armed men attack a mission near Rwanda, killing an Italian volunteer, a Croatian Nun, and injuring others.
Unknown attacks murder a prominent human rights activist at his home.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: Gunmen, believed to be from the DRC, shot dead two policemen at a checkpoint and one attacker was killed in an exchange of fire.
An armed gang kidnapped, killed and dismembered an albino girl in what was Burundis 18th such slaying in less than four years.
An albino civilian was killed in the night in the commune of Kabezi, south of Bujumbura, by unknown attackers.
Villagers in northeast Burundi hacked to death a woman accused of witchcraft and five members of her family, including a baby and two other children.
Five members of a family were killed with machetes in the night for having dark beliefs.
INEC hold 2 day meeting on strengthening democratic culture for good organization of the elections of 2015 with delegates from different provinces.
Unidentified people blasted a grenade in a house at Vuaya, killing three persons and seriously injuring three others
Grenade blast kills 2, injures 18 in Burundis Gitega province
